issue.title: The 2FA/MFA setup screen is confusing
issue.body: When a user gets added or invited to a site which requires multi-factor authentication to be enabled on their account, the initial MFA setup workflow is very confusing. It appears to be optimised for allowing users to use more than one MFA method, but I would expect the most common use case is using one MFA method. ## Screenshot This is the interstitial MFA configuration screen that a user sees after signing in for the first time. You can trigger this on an account by deleting the `_two_factor_*` user meta fields for a user. ## Problems * If a user wants to use TOTP with Google Authenticator, Authy, 1Password, etc, they have to click three buttons: the "Enabled" checkbox, the "Primary" radio button, and the "View Options" toggle. If they fail to click all three of those then the setup fails. * There's no client-side checking of the required TOTP code field * No error message is shown if the user submits the form without having filled out everything they need to. * There's an unnecessary distinction between enabled and primary on this screen - how many users use multiple MFA methods compared to those who just use one? * The user is not reminded or forced to generate backup verification codes, greatly increasing the probability of them locking themselves out of their account if they lose access to their MFA method. * Being able to select "Backup Verification Codes" as the primary or default MFA method makes no sense. * The empty "Security Keys" listing table at the bottom of the screen makes no sense. This should only be displayed after the user chooses the FIDO option and sets up a new key. * It should not be possible to set an MFA method as "Primary" without it also being "Enabled".

issue.title: The 2FA/MFA setup screen is confusing
issue.body: When a user gets added or invited to a site which requires multi-factor authentication to be enabled on their account, the initial MFA setup workflow is very confusing. It appears to be optimised for allowing users to use more than one MFA method, but I would expect the most common use case is using one MFA method. ## Screenshot This is the interstitial MFA configuration screen that a user sees after signing in for the first time. You can trigger this on an account by deleting the `_two_factor_*` user meta fields for a user. ## Problems * If a user wants to use TOTP with Google Authenticator, Authy, 1Password, etc, they have to click three buttons: the "Enabled" checkbox, the "Primary" radio button, and the "View Options" toggle. If they fail to click all three of those then the setup fails. * There's no client-side checking of the required TOTP code field * No error message is shown if the user submits the form without having filled out everything they need to. * There's an unnecessary distinction between enabled and primary on this screen - how many users use multiple MFA methods compared to those who just use one? * The user is not reminded or forced to generate backup verification codes, greatly increasing the probability of them locking themselves out of their account if they lose access to their MFA method. * Being able to select "Backup Verification Codes" as the primary or default MFA method makes no sense. * The empty "Security Keys" listing table at the bottom of the screen makes no sense. This should only be displayed after the user chooses the FIDO option and sets up a new key. * It should not be possible to set an MFA method as "Primary" without it also being "Enabled".

comment.body: Thanks for the issue @johnbillion; as this is a wide-ranging set of improvements, not directly a bug, can you file this via the Altis Dashboard roadmap's suggestions instead please? Cheers!

issue.title: The 2FA/MFA setup screen is confusing
issue.body: When a user gets added or invited to a site which requires multi-factor authentication to be enabled on their account, the initial MFA setup workflow is very confusing. It appears to be optimised for allowing users to use more than one MFA method, but I would expect the most common use case is using one MFA method. ## Screenshot This is the interstitial MFA configuration screen that a user sees after signing in for the first time: ## Problems * If a user wants to use TOTP with Google Authenticator, Authy, 1Password, etc, they have to click three buttons: the "Enabled" checkbox, the "Primary" radio button, and the "View Options" toggle. If they fail to click all three of those then the setup fails. * There's no client-side checking of the required TOTP code field * No error message is shown if the user submits the form without having filled out everything they need to. * There's an unnecessary distinction between enabled and primary on this screen - how many users use multiple MFA methods compared to those who just use one? * The user is not reminded or forced to generate backup verification codes, greatly increasing the probability of them locking themselves out of their account if they lose access to their MFA method. * Being able to select "Backup Verification Codes" as the primary or default MFA method makes no sense. * The empty "Security Keys" listing table at the bottom of the screen makes no sense. This should only be displayed after the user chooses the FIDO option and sets up a new key. * It should not be possible to set an MFA method as "Primary" without it also being "Enabled".

payload.description: Juniper is the web style guide and pattern library for Human Made projects.

commits.message: Build v2.1.0

Update typography styles.  (#172)

* Update code styles for consistency with eng handbook

* Code docs

* Better list indentation

* HR in sample docs

* tighten up typography

Co-authored-by: Matthew Haines-Young <matthew@humanmade.com>

pull_request.title: Update typography styles.
pull_request.body:
I'm looking at fixing a few style issues in the Engineering Handbook, where Ryan has overridden some of the pattern library styles. I think he was trying to tighten the text styles up a bit, reducing some excess margins etc. to improve legibility.

* Reduce margins between paragraphs. 
* Reduce bottom margin on headings. 
* Improve list styles
* Add hr styles
* Reduce blockquote margins.
* Improve code text styles. Apply font-family and other styles to non prism code blocks.

issue.title: Image upload fails
issue.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54251966/168957206-46e69cf4-0e86-402e-a3c9-32e2d49e1be4.png)

Getting post processing failed error when uploading image.

Also on S3 bucket the image shows up under upload fodler but just a 0KB corrupt file.

I am running WordPress 5.8.2 and S3 Uploads Version 2.2.2

comment.body: Also having the same issue, minus the processing failure message

Merge pull request #387 from humanmade/backport-384-to-v4-6-branch

[Backport v4-6-branch] Prevent fatal error if aggregations are empty

Switch to intersection observers for tracking XB views

There was a problem with the earlier scroll tracking behaviour not triggering on first load, so some events were not being picked up.

Additionally once that was resaolved I observed double tracking of events caused by not clearing the queue early enough and a race-condition happening.Needs further work in a future update to make delivery more robust.

Fixes https://github.com/humanmade/product-dev/issues/1004
Add intersection observer to IE11 polyfill

Handle cron schedules being null

We had a case where some 3rd party code is setting `$schedules` to null.
